titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Sunday. VII: A long morning visit from G. Blake, who is about to leave the City and return to Boston. I had visits also from Judge Story; Mr Wheaton, the Reporter of the decisions of the Supreme Court, and two young men from Rhode-Island, Brown and Ives— I walked an hour before dinner with a heavy shower of Rain, and was engaged all the remainder of the day and Evening, in reading and writing. My wife being still confined to her chamber, and Susan Buchanan passed the day at Mr Frye’s.

2. VI: At the President’s I met Mr Crawford; and enquired if he had any remarks to make on my draft of a Letter to Mr Onis; he said he had some; but had reserved them for the general Cabinet meeting at which he had expected it would be considered— The President had told me it would be sufficient to give it separately to each of the heads of departments, for examination and remark, without submitting it to a cabinet meeting. Now however he directed a meeting for that purpose to-morrow at Noon— And at my request the Answer to be given to Mr Pazos, is also to be then considered— The President likewise told me, that Mr L. Harris had been with him, and with many declarations of his respect for me, and his belief of my integrity, had intimated the possibility that I might be under some prejudice, or prepossession against him; and wished that the charges against him, and his defence of himself might be referred to two others of the heads of Departments to Report upon the whole subject to him— I told the President, I should be perfectly satisfied that the affair should take this course, or any other that would be satisfactory to him and Mr Harris, and relieve me from having any thing further to do with the affair. I had candidly told Harris my opinion upon his case, and that if he had continued in Office, I should have felt it my duty to pursue the subject further. But that as he was no longer in the public service, I was under no obligation to act upon it— I knew indeed that he was desirous of obtaining a new appointment, and if he could satisfy the President of his integrity, he might apply directly to him, without addressing himself at all to the Department of State— I should be satisfied with any determination the President should finally make in the case; provided my opinion concerning it should not be asked— Mr A. H. Everett came to the Office; and also dined with us. Susan Buchanan went to a Ball at Mr Bagot’s.

3. V:30.Dr Bates called this morning at my house, and is going to-morrow for Boston. I went to the President’s at Noon, where there was a full Cabinet-Meeting. My draft of a Note to Onis, was read and discussed— Many further alterations suggested— Many passages struck out, and one considerable omission noticed by Mr Crawford. It was on a topic which had been so completely discussed at Aranjuez, that I had omitted it, merely to avoid useless repetition. But Mr Crawford thought that this paper ought to contain a complete exposition of our whole controversy with Spain, and that no essential part of our argument ought to be omitted even if it was contained in previous papers; I acquiesced in his opinion, though the President thought that the addition of one or two sentences would be sufficient— There was also some consideration about the answer to be given to Mr Pazos, and finally determined that I should draft a written answer, to be considered by the President— It was just upon five when the meeting broke up, and on going to my Office, Mr Brent and all the Clerks were gone. It was past six when I got home. My wife is still obliged to keep her bed the greater part of the day, though she rode out this morning. Susan Buchanan went and passed the night at Mrs Frye’s, whose twins are again dying. I was the whole evening occupied in drafting the addition to the Note for Onis— Up till near Midnight. I had this Morning on the way to the President’s met Mr Silsbee, who spoke to me again about his claim upon the monies recovered at Algiers, upon the Negotiation of Decatur’s Treaty. Another claimant has it seems obtained more than his share, and Silsbee is not willing to be satisfied with what is left. But I am not authorized to judge between adverse claims to the Money; and still less between a claim yet open, and one already settled— I also called at Pleasonton’s Office and asked him to revise with the Comptroller my Account, to make the settlement of it conformable to the principles upon which the Accounts of Mr Clay and Mr Gallatin, have been settled— He asked me to speak with the Comptroller about it.

4. VI: Finished the draft of the supplementary sheet for the note to Mr Onis— Called at the Office of the Comptroller, Mr Anderson, and had some conversation with him on the subject of my Accounts. He appeared to be convinced that some of the charges disallowed by him in my accounts ought to be allowed. Pleasonton the Auditor came in while I was there, and started a new objection, though he has always hinted to me that the objections all came from the comptroller— At the President’s, I met Mr Calhoun— Mr Silsbee and Pleasonton afterwards came to the Office, and there was much discussion concerning Silsbee’s claim— It was again about six in the Evening when I came home— Susan Buchanan came back from Mrs Frye’s, where the children are dying. My wife is still confined to her chamber— The day began with rain, which turned to hail and sleet and finished with a Snow-Storm— I drafted a Letter to V. Pazos, and a Note to ten Cate.

5. VI:Mr Walsh sent me another paper that he has prepared on the affair of Amelia-Island, and afterwards called himself. There were several passages, which I thought questionable, and which he will publish or omit as he thinks proper— He publishes these papers of his own accord; he gave me before he began them that he intended to write and publish on the subject, in support of the President’s measures; and has sent me all the papers in manuscript, before they were published— I have marked a very few passages in the former papers and several in this one, as taking views of the subject, different from mine. He has hitherto altered or omitted the passages which I have marked. I called at Pleasonton’s this day and had further conversation with him concerning my accounts— At the President’s I read to him the drafts of Letters to Ten Cate, and Pazos— Ten Cate had asked for an interview and came at two O’Clock— It was merely to ask an answer to the Letter he had written to me, about the tonnage duties the 13th. of last Month— I read to him the answer with which he was satisfied, and it was sent to him in the course of the day. The Letter to Pazos was also sent— My wife was able this day to come down to dinner, the first time these ten days— N. Pope spent the Evening with us till near Midnight.

6. VI:30. Drafted answer to a Letter received yesterday from the Danish Minister Resident and Consul General Pedersen. G. Blake called at my House and detained me in Conversation till after One O’Clock— I found the President unwell, with a severe cold and cough; and with an apparent depression of Spirits. At the Office I was occupied, all the time that I had, in looking up and preparing the papers to be communicated to Congress relating to the Negotiation with Spain. There was an Evening party at Decatur’s to which Susan Buchanan went. My wife was not well enough, and I had not time to go. Mr Correa spent an hour with us this Evening, and told me that he had received instructions from his Government to make representations concerning the capture of three Portuguese Vessels by these pirating privateers. He said there was a great mass of documents with them to which he should only refer as being ready to produce them if required; and he hoped a conciliatory answer would be given him—something about the American interests, to keep the mind of his king inclined to remain in America, according to the system which was always maintained by the late Count da Barca (Araujo.) I promised him as favourable an answer as I should be able to give on receiving his Note. I made drafts of a short Letter to Mr Onis, and one to J. Dick—District Attorney at New Orleans, on the case of Mr Morphy.

7. V:30.General S. Smith of Baltimore called at my house this Morning to make enquiries what advice I had received in England at the time of the violent inflammation of the eyes with which I was afflicted there. His wife Mrs Smith, is suffering very severely in the same manner; which obliged him to go to Baltimore for some days. He came back yesterday— He took occasion to hint again the desire of his Son, to go abroad in a public Character, and said we should want a rich man to go to Russia. I drafted a Report to the President on the papers to be submitted to Congress relative to the Spanish Negotiation. By his direction I left it with him. At the Office I had a succession of visitors, all the morning. Judge Lucas of the Missouri territory; very much dissatisfied with the nomination and appointment of R. Wash as U.S. Attorney for that territory. I told him that Wash was recommended by the Governor of the territory Clarke. He said he supposed so, and it was the worst recommendation that could have been given— That territory has been torn to pieces by opposite factions ever since it was constituted; and Lucas has been one of the most ardent partizans among them— His Son was the last U.S. Attorney there, and was killed last Summer in a duel, which sprung from these party feuds. Lucas spoke also against a Captain O’Fallon who is also a Candidate to be receiver of monies at a new Land-Office opened there, and is recommended also by Governor Clarke, and by J and N. Pope— Lucas hinted that the Governor, and Wash and O’Fallon all had
a personal interest to favour a certain unfounded claim to lead mines in the territory, called Dubuc’s claim, which Mr Gallatin had declared to be unwarranted, for which he referred me to the compilation of the land-laws— He said also that Wash had published an unprovoked and insolent pamphlet against him; and as evidence that he himself took no part in the political contests, he stated that he had not voted at all at the last election of a delegate for the Territory; when the contest was between Scott and Easton. He said there had been two other Candidates for the Office of Attorney, besides Wash— Mr Chamberlin and Mr Wheler, both New-Englandmen—respectable and quiet characters. He himself so far as he could be considered an American, was a Pennsylvanian (He is a native of France.) but he had wished Mr Chamberlin or Mr Wheler might have had the appointment; to give more weight in the Territory to the peaceable tranquil character of New-England; instead of the restless and turbulent, and overbearing Spirit of Virginia and Kentucky— Master Lucas is a knowing one; and thought he knew his man, when he said this— He would not have talked thus to the President— Mr Roberts of the Senate came next, to have some conversation with me, about a claim of Major Miller, for which he has petitioned Congress. He was followed by G. Blake, who came for a written statement concerning his official conduct on some of the South-American privateering Affairs— He sent this Statement to the President, and wishes now to have it returned— It cannot be found at the President’s— I advised Blake to see Mr Crawford, the Secretary of the Treasury, and explain to him the transaction of his going to Portland— He asked me from whom the information of the fact had come— I told him from the Collector at Portland. He went accordingly to Mr Crawford at the Treasury. The two Members of the House of Representatives from Rhode-Island, Burrell and Boss, and the Senator, Hunter came to make an application in favour of T. L. Halsey late Consul at Buenos Ayres; and they brought me a Letter from some American lately from Buenos Ayres, to Halsey’s father expressing his belief that Halsey had not been concerned in the Buenos Ayres privateering— I shewed to these Gentlemen Halsey’s own Letter to De Wolfe, and all the blank Commissions he had sent for a privateer, to which they had nothing to reply— Mr Otis and R. G. Amory then came, and made application in behalf of W. Clarke, as Consul at Amsterdam. Mr. H. Johnson newly appointed a Senator from the State of Louisiana brought me Letters of Introduction from T. B. Johnson, and J. Winthrop, at New-Orleans. These visitors kept me constantly engaged till past four O’Clock, and it was near six when I came home. I had stopped at the Branch Bank, and received 172 dollars 54 Cents for Charles Newcomb, for dividends on 6 and 3 per Cent U.S. Stocks for which I gave a receipt as his Attorney— The Power had been sent me by my brother and I left it at the Bank. The Dividends were from 1. Jany 1796 to 30. June 1816— I took a draft on the Branch Bank at Boston for the Money— This Evening I wrote to my brother. I returned to W. S. Smith at his request a Letter that he had written me to ask for a loan of money.

8. V:45. I intended to have gone this morning to Church; but Cardelli the Sculptor came in just at the hour, and detained me at home— He is in a state of despair because Coll. Lane the Commissioner of the Public Buildings, and Mr Bulfinch the Architect, insist upon his working at the ornaments of the Capitol, instead of designing and executing Basso-relievos, and the proper business of a Sculptor— The degradation from an Artist to a workman cuts him to the Soul; yet he is reduced by necessity to submit to it. Mrs Adams with Susan Buchanan paid several visits and the Carriage got stuck so that they were obliged to get out and borrow Mr Orr’s horses to bring it home. I returned visits to Mr and Mrs Sears, General A. Smyth—Mr H. Johnson the Senator, to R. G. Amory, G. Blake and Mr Mills— Mr Horsey the Senator from Delaware was with them at Queen’s— At Judge Story’s, I met Genl. Harper, and I left a card for Mr Wheaton at Bailey’s. The remainder of the day and Evening I was constantly engaged in writing. Finished the draft of a Report to the President on the late Negotiation of Messrs. Eustis and Gallatin, and wrote several Letters. Susan Buchanan spent the Evening abroad, and the Carriage got stuck again coming home. The horses were taken out, and the Carriage left standing in the Street before our door till Morning.

9. VI:15. I called at Pleasonton’s Office about my Accounts. L. Harris was there— In explaining some of the charges against which objections are made, I found that Pleasonton who is the Auditor left the whole business to a Clerk in his Office, named Ross; and whenever I shewed Pleasonton that he had committed an error in the examination he was obliged to call up Ross to explain how it had happened— They insisted that I had charged twice over a Plate for Passports in England— The last time I saw Pleasonton I proved to him that it was not and could not be so— He was then fully convinced; but this day without a shadow of reason he had got it into his head again; and I was obliged to prove again not only to him but to his Clerk Ross that they were mistaken; and even then he would not give it up— This to my extreme Mortification put me out of temper, and I scolded Pleasonton in a manner richly deserved by him, but most unworthy of me— Ross told me that if I had produced no vouchers at all, for contingencies, he would have passed all my charges without asking a question; but as I had produced vouchers he allowed nothing, that was not vouched— I had expressly told Pleasonton that there were some charges for which I had taken no vouchers, and could take none— But Pleasonton had not told Ross this and now persevered in cavilling and quibbling against conviction— I called at Mr Anderson the Comptroller’s Office; and there found a Mr Casaux, a Canadian, complaining that Congress had last Session, been swindled out of a law granting upwards of 40000 dollars to a pretended agent of his father’s; and asserting that his claim as the representative of his father was still unsatisfied. This law of last Session was obtained by Captain Stuart, who went to England as Coll. Aspinwall’s Secretary, and there got hold of this claim through Grubb, from a man named Corbaux, who pretended to be Assignee and Attorney irrevocable of Casaux— Corbaux did apply to me about the claim, while I was in England, and I thought it not worth a dollar— At the President’s I left with him my Report on the late Negotiation in Holland— At the Office, I had Mr Bagot conversing two hours upon various subjects— The recovery of deserting Seamen—Colonial trade; the Plaister of Paris Law in New Brunswic and its repeal; and the disarming on the Lakes. I have no time to detail the particulars of our Conversation upon these points though on all it was important— Mrs Adams spent the Evening with Susan Buchanan at Mrs Sergeant’s— A. H. Everett spent it with me.

10. VI.Mr John O’Sullivan came to my house. He had obtained a Commission as Consul at Mogadore in the Empire of Morocco; which having been found contrary to the Law of 1. May 1810 was a few days since revoked. He now came to ask for the appointment as Consul at Teneriffe, and having heard complaints against his conduct had been made wished to be informed what they were, and an opportunity to refute them. He was aware they had been made by Captain Riley, and attributed them to resentment at his having taken measures while as Consul at Mogadore, to vindicate the reputation of certain merchants there, defamed by Captain Riley’s Narrative. I told him that I had received a Letter from Captain Riley containing imputations against him— That the substance of them should be made known to him, and an opportunity given him to justify himself against them. Afterwards I received a Letter from him asking for a copy of Riley’s Letter against him— When I called at the President’s, he was out riding; but on his return he sent me word he was at home, and I went to him— General P. B. Porter and Elliot the Printer were at the Office— The former, about a second Resolution of the House of Representatives, asking for information of the expences incident to the Ghent Treaty Commissions, and the latter upon a Petition to the House of Representatives, asking for the Patronage of Congress to a project of printing two or three Volumes of domestic State papers; which Petition, the House have referred to the Secretary of State— Elliot is to furnish me a paper containing the particulars of his plan, and a list of the documents he proposes to publish— I called at the Office of the Secretary of War, but did not find him—and at that of the Secretary of the Navy to make arrangements for the sailing of the Hornet, Captain Read which is to take Taylor and Lewis to St. Domingo, Irvine to Terra Firma, and then to go to Copenhagen for the mutineers of the Plattsburg— There was some question whether the order of the West-India stages of the Voyage should not be changed; but we concluded to leave it as it had been settled— I had called again at Pleasonton’s Office this Morning about my accounts, and had gone further explanation with him and Ross concerning them— I admitted some of the deductions which they had made; all that upon examination I had found to be errors in my accounts; and they amounted altogether only to a few dollars— I also proved to them again their own errors, which they at last both admitted— I am now to see the Comptroller on the principle of allowance which they have adopted, and stated my objections to it in writing. General Harper spent the Evening with us. Received a Note from the Abbe Correa, to say that he is going to Baltimore— Frye’s twins have both died; one the day before yesterday, and the other yesterday.

11. VI: Going out this morning, Mr N. Pope overtook and walked with me. Told me of a suicide committed last Night at Davis’s Hotel where he lodges, by a young man, named Johnson— I called at the Office of Mr Anderson the Comptroller, with my Letter to him respecting my Accounts. He admits that there must be a revision of the Account, as he had passed it, but appears inflexible upon the only material charge that he disallowed. I conclude the revision will be as far from doing me justice as the prior settlement. At my Office there came a young man named Mitchell, son to the Consul at St. Pierre’s Martinique, and told me that Coll. Gardiner, Chief Clerk of the Land-Office, died suddenly last Evening, of an Apoplectic fit; leaving his family in great distress— Mr Young sent me this morning the original of Alcedo’s dictionary, in which I found several articles, much to the purpose of my Note to Mr Onis— I therefore sent for the Book to the Office, and Mr Purviance translated the extracts— The most important of them is omitted from Thompson’s translation of Alcedo— We attended this Evening at Mrs Monroe’s drawing Room. It was less crowded than the two former at which we have been— I had some conversation with Mr Lowndes the chairman of the Committee of ways and means, concerning the Appropriations for Salaries of Agencies for Seamen, and for the Ghent Treaty Commissions— We were obliged to go to the President’s in a Hack, our horses having escaped from the stable— They were not recovered this Night.

12. VI:15. Our horses were brought home this Morning, having strayed in the Night three Miles from the house. Going this Morning to the President’s I met Mr Jonathan Mason, who walked with me, and gave me a letter from Mrs M. Babcock to him containing an application for the appointment of her Son, Henry Babcock as Consular Agent at the Isle of Bourbon; where he has been residing these ten years; with a certificate in his favour from several respectable Merchants of Boston— I shewed these papers to the President who directed that the appointment should be made. At the Office, Ross the Clerk in Pleasonton’s Office came again to discuss the question about the mode of calculating the number of days for the fractions of Quarters in my accounts, at the commencement and close of my late mission in Europe— I told him that my first account being for a quarter and part of another quarter, I had calculated for the number of days in proportion to the year; and the last account being for part of a quarter, I had reckoned for the number of days in proportion to the whole Quarter; and after this explanation I told him I would contend no more about it—they might settle it as they pleased. L. Harris came to the Office, and expressed his concern at the prejudices which he thought I entertained against his conduct while Consul in Russia— I told him that all the papers charging him, and in his defence, had been transmitted to Mr Crawford and Mr Calhoun, who were to report to the President upon the case. That I had not communicated to them the information, which I had received from Mr Rodde of Revel, nor should I, unless called upon by them to know, if I had any information upon the subject, say any thing to them about it— That if they should call upon me, I had a minute of what Rodde told me, taken in writing at the time (v. Journal 14. May 1814 vol. 4. p. 102.) the substance of which I should state to them. He desired me, if that should be the case, I would also point the attention of those Gentlemen to the letter from the same D. Rodde to him, which he has promised in his defence, which I promised him I would— He also spoke about his nephew J. L. Harris, and his quarrel with Lewis. He was very sorry to find upon examination that his nephew had been wrong in his conduct on that affair, and the President had consented that without any open or express removal of young Harris; he Levett should write to him, and advise him to come home— I told him that would be the best manner of terminating the affair, and of sparing the feelings of all the parties— I called upon Mr Calhoun, the Secretary of War, and left with him C. Newcomb’s papers forwarded by my brother— Mr Calhoun thinks the vote upon the South American Independence question in the House of Representatives, will be very strong in support of the course pursued by the Administration. I am not quite so confident. The vote on Pazos’s Memorial, yesterday was 124. to 28. Sergeant asked me last Evening if there would be any objection to a call from the house for the papers addressed by Pazos to the Executive— I mentioned it this Morning to the President, who said he had no objection to communicate them at all— My wife was unwell this Evening.

13. V. Draft of answer to a Note from the Portuguese Minister Correa— Met Mr Crawford at the President’s. Mr O’Sullivan came to my house again this Morning, to ask for a copy of Captain Riley’s Letter against him— Mr Brent, at my request had informed Riley that O’Sullivan had asked for this paper— Riley was apprehensive that he wanted to make it the ground of a challenge— I therefore told O’Sullivan that I should let him know whatever was of a nature to require any explanation from him; but upon condition that it should not lead to any personal altercation with any one. He gave me his word of honour that he would make no other use of it than for his own vindication against unjust charges— At the Office we finally made up, and I signed the Note to Onis, which was sent to him. We had an evening tea party of about fifty persons.

14. VI:15.G. Blake came this Morning, and took leave, on his return to Boston. The Supreme Court of the United States closed their Session this day. At the Offices of Pleasonton the 5th. Auditor and Anderson the Comptroller about my Accounts. At the President’s, he gave me the draft of his Message to Congress, on the Spanish Negotiation; for two Copies of it to be made at the Office. They were made, and two copies of my Report, and of all the papers were sent to him; and by him to the two Houses. Mr Everett called at the Office: going early to-morrow Morning for Boston. He promised to call again this Evening at my house, but did not. Mr R. King was at the Office, and I had a long conversation with him, on the general state of affairs. Susan Buchanan passed the day at Mrs Frye’s, and did not come back this Evening.

15. VI:Mr Gales, one of the Editors of the National Intelligencer came with the budget of Papers of the Spanish Negotiation, which are too voluminous, for a newspaper, and which he had thoughts of publishing in a Supplement of three or four sheets, which he said would cost 150 dollars. He finally concluded to give a short abstract of the papers communicated to Congress, and the closing part only of my note to Mr Onis— I walked to the Potowmack Bridge, and nearly over it— Returning home, I met R. Walsh who came in with me, and sat with me half an hour— He says Mr Correa, is at Baltimore, sick— D. Brent was here, while I was out this morning, and again in the Evening. Mrs Adams went to Mrs Frye’s, and brought back Susan Buchanan. I am suffering with the tooth-ache, and it partly disabled me from writing this Evening.

16. VI: Restless Night. At the President’s I saw Mr and Mrs Hay. The President who has taken a new Cold, upon a severe one that he had before, had some fever, and by advice of his physician Doctor Shoaf keeps his bed— I did not see him. At the Office there came successively General S. Smith of Baltimore, Mr Lowndes, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, Judge Tait, Senator of the United States from Georgia, with Mr Crowell, Delegate in Congress from the Alabama Territory, just arrived— And Captain James Riley. Smith came to complain of one of Mr Rush’s opinions while Attorney General; concerning bounties given for British Prisoners during the War— Mr Lowndes came to make some enquiries concerning the Ghent Treaty Commissions, and he told me the Committee of Ways and Means, had agreed to continue the appropriation for a Salary to the Agent of Claims at Copenhagen, for nine Months of the present year, to mark their opinion that it should be continued no longer. Mr Crowell brought me a Letter from Governor Bibb, of the Alabama Territory, with a drawing for a territorial Seal. Captain Riley came to enquire if I should Report soon, in answer to enquiries from the chairman of the Committee of Foreign Relations, Mr Forsyth, concerning the Consulate of Morocco; and the claims of James Simpson the Consul. I examined the Correspondence of Coll. Humphreys relating to the subject, and this Evening finished the draft of a Report— I still suffered all day with the tooth-ache, and this evening felt a lassitude, and drowsiness which almost prevented me from writing.

17. VI: Found Mr Crawford at the President’s with Mr Hay, and Mr J. J. Monroe, the President has a fever, and is confined to his chamber; we were again requested to postpone seeing him upon business till to morrow. I had prepared a Report upon the issue of the Negotiation in the Netherlands, which the President had approved, and with which he was to have sent a Message to Congress; but Mr Crawford upon consultation with General S. Smith that it would be better to assume a broader principle, and offer the abolition of all discriminating duties to every European Nation, that will do the same. Mr Crawford had made a draft of a Bill, to that effect; in three Sections, which he shewed to me, and afterwards to Crowninshield, who came in— We had some loose discussion upon it, to be resumed if the President can attend to business to-morrow. There was also some talk about the Society for the Colonization of Blacks; of which Crawford is a member and Vice-President, and at which he laughed heartily. He told me that Clay was endeavouring to make my Letter to Onis ridiculous, and that a tremendous storm would burst upon me about the affair of Amelia Island— Crowninshield had Letters from Amelia Island, saying
that Aury had left it, with two vessels. Mr Van Ness was at the Office to speak again about the expences of the Ghent Treaty Commissions; and young Fenwick to ask an appointment as one of the Additional Clerks contemplated to be appointed for the Department. Mrs Adams and Susan Buchanan spent the Evening at Mrs Boyd’s. I partly drafted an answer to three Notes from Mr Hyde de Neuville.

18. V:45. Walking this Morning to the President, I met Mr Bagot who turned and walked with me. He told me that he had received Letters from Admiral Milne commanding on the Jamaica Station, informing him that he had issued orders similar to those of last year, to seize all American Vessels, which may be found fishing within the British Jurisdiction; and that he could not take upon himself the responsibility of counteracting those orders. He had been promised a proposal from us, ever since last May, and had received none yet— I told him that the President’s illness had prevented it— That upon full enquiry it had been found that we could not safely accept any particular limited bounds for fishing grounds; because the fish resorted at different times to different places— That Lord Castlereagh had promised me, he would direct certain statements to be furnished to us, upon which we might have founded proposals which was not done; that he should counteract Admiral Milne’s Order, because the judge at Halifax had decided last year that those seizures were unlawful without an Act of Parliament— That I was afraid we should have to fight for this matter in the end, and I was so confident of our right that I was for it— He said the correctness of the judge’s decision was very doubtful. That Great-Britain had gone as far in this affair to accommodate us as she could go; and he thought would do nothing further &c. He thanked me for having set Mr Onis right, in my note to him, about a British Mediation; and said Onis’s statement of the case must have been a wilful misrepresentation— At the President’s we saw him in his Bedchamber— Met there Mr Crawford; who upon reflection has concluded not to press his Bill for the repeal of all discriminating duties; but to leave it on the foundation of my Report, and so that Congress if they choose to go further may do it of their own movement. The President asked me to draft a Message for him to send in with my Report— At the Office, I had as visitors, Genl. John Mason, W. Lee and Mr Hyde de Neuville the French Minister, and Mr Calhoun. Mason came about a Letter from J. S. S. at Baltimore, concerning M’Gregor; and enclosing one from M’Gregor to him. Mason had given these Letters to the President; who now enquired whether Mason was willing they should be communicated to Congress. Mason has written to enquire of Skinner, who in his answer demurs, but in another private Note to Mason adds circumstantial instances in proof of M’Gregor’s want of principle and veracity. Mason said he would write again to Skinner on the subject. Lee came to give me a hint on a very ridiculous affair; but which shews how I am situated; my office as Secretary of State; makes it the interest of all the partizans of the Candidates for the next Presidency to say no more; to deny me as much as possible in the public opinion— The most conspicuous of these Candidates, are Crawford, the Secretary of the Treasury, Clay, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, and DeWitt Clinton, Governor of New York. Clay expected himself to have been Secretary of State, and he and all his creatures were disappointed by my appointment. He is therefore coming out as the head of a new Opposition in Congress to Mr Monroe’s Administration; and he makes no scruple of giving the tone to all his party in running me down— On the publication of the concluding part of my late Letter to Onis, he went about the House of Representatives, shewing and sneering at a passage where it is said that the United States after waiting thirteen years for justice from Spain, could without much effort wait somewhat longer. Clinton’s party operate in another way— There was published lately in the National Advocate, a New York Newspaper in opposition to Clinton, a Letter purporting to be from an agent of Clinton’s to another named Asahal Clark, and detailing a journey of intrigue in the State of Vermont, to secure partizans in favour of Clinton. The Letter is signed E. W. Robinson— Clark who is a real personage and now at Washington has published repeated disavowals of having ever been engaged in any such transactions, and certificates that there is no such person in Vermont, as E. W. Robinson— The Letter appears therefore to be a forgery, and the Clintonian’s turn it back as a battery against the National Advocate and its Editor M. M. Noah. Lee’s visit to me, was to tell me, that it was whispered
about that Noah had received a Letter franked by me; and that it was to advise him to say no more about the Robinson Letter. The remarkable part of this affair, is that Noah did actually receive lately a Letter from me, which was to call upon him to refund to the Government of the United States, a sum of 1000 dollars, which Noah, upon being recalled from Tunis as Consul of the United States there, had left due for two years house rent, and which Mr Shaler upon his late visit to Tunis, found himself bound to pay, from the public monies— On these facts I observe three things— 1. The espionage of Clinton’s partizans, discovering the fact that Noah had received a Letter, franked by me. 2. Their suspicious inference that a letter to Noah franked by me, must relate to the Robinson Letter. 3. Their policy, in circulating a report founded on this false inference, that I am intriguing underhandedly against Clinton, and had some concern in the publication of the Robinson Letter— Of Crawford’s rivalry, I have yet had no other evidence than what has seemed to me a sort of effort to differ from me in opinions concerning the important measures to be pursued by the administration; & a disposition to impress upon my Mind, every particular of Clay’s operations against me— When Everett was here he asked me, if it would not be advisable, to expose Clay’s conduct and motives in the Newspapers, to which I answered very explicitly in the negative— He also asked me if I was determined to do nothing with a view to promote my future election to the Presidency as the successor of Mr Monroe— I told him I should do absolutely nothing— He said that as others would not be so scrupulous, I should not stand upon equal footing with them— I told him that was not my fault. My business was to serve the public to the best of my abilities, in the station assigned to me, and not to intrigue for further advancement— I never by the most distant hint to any one ever expressed a wish for any public Office; and I should not now begin to ask, for that which of all others ought to be most freely and spontaneously bestowed— Mr De Neuville’s visit was to speak upon various subjects concerning which he has written to me—Lawrence Haff—Le Gros, the French vessels carried to Amelia-Island; but especially the expedition of the L’Allemands, who he says have arrived at New Orleans; and of their Associates who have landed at Galvezton— He says Onis has protested to him upon his honour, that he knows nothing of them or their project— I told him he might rely upon it that Onis did know something of them— He said that as they were Frenchmen, and most of them might return to France if they chose, it would be equally displeasing to his Government, whether their projects were against the United States or Spain— Mr Sergeant spent a couple of hours with me, this Evening— The subject of the Neutrality Laws is before Congress. Mr Clay pushes for the repeal of Laws, which trammel the means of giving aid to the South-American Revolutionists; and there is no member of the House of Representatives friendly to the Administration, who has Spirit, and Ability and Mastery of the Subject, adequate to withstand him— The federalists hitherto have taken little or no share in the debate.

19. VII. I drafted a Message to be sent to Congress with my Report on the Commercial Negotiation with the Netherlands which I took to the President’s, and it was approved by him. Elliot the Editor of the City of Washington Gazette, was at the Office— He has petitioned Congress, for their patronage to the publication of two or three Volumes of Domestic State Papers—and the House of Representatives have referred his petition to the Secretary of State— I first desired him to send me an account of his plans for the publication; and now asked him for a list of the documents that he intends to republish; which he promised to send me. Mr Irving, member of the house of Representatives from the City of New-York, came to testify in favour of the character of Mr John O’Sullivan, which has been assailed by Captain Riley— At home this Evening I began the draft of Remarks on the Memorial of V. Pazos to the President— The day before yesterday our Coachman Joseph Homey, left us, and the black man Henrywho was with Mr Gallatin at Ghent came in his place.

20. VI. Good Friday— At the President’s I found him convalescent— Received a Note from Mr Bagot, requesting an interview; for which to-morrow at 2. O’Clock was appointed. Dr Thornton was at the Office with an application, for an increase of his Salary as superintendent of the Patent Office. He brought me Certificates from Mr Monroe, and Mr Rush in favour of such an increase— I told the Doctor that Congress had undertaken to arrange that affair by Law— He also brought me the deeds by Lease and Release, which he was executing of an Estate of his own in England; to ask my advice about it— L. Harris came and withdrew a paper addressed by him to Mr Crawford, concerning his affair— Mr Crawford and Mr Calhoun have made a Report, concerning it to the President, and the Papers have been returned to the Department of State. The Report is indecisive— Mr Frye, spent an hour with us at our house this Evening.

21. VII.Mr Walsh called upon me this Morning. He proposed to me, to write further on the South-American and Amelia-Island questions: but his views do not exactly accord with mine. He is one of the ablest, and most powerful writers in this Country; but like many other ingenious men, has annihilated his own influence, by the prejudices that he has adopted and maintained— Mr Otis came to my house with Mr Holley late of Boston; going now to be President of the Transylvania University in Kentucky. Mr Holley brought Letters from my father and mother— It was so late when I went out that I could not call at the President’s. It was an extremely violent Storm of wind and rain which continued the whole day. I rode to and from my Office. Susan Buchanan went to Mr Frye’s, and remains there this Night— At the Office, Mr Baldwin of New-York called, about the remission of the fine in a case of forfeiture—the Hervey Hide— Mr Bagot, brought me, a Letter from the Collector of the Customs at New-Brunswick to the Commissioners of the Customs, in England complaining of our Fishermen, on the Coasts of these British Provinces. He also said something about the Salaries of the Commissioners under the Ghent Treaty Articles— I was deeply engaged at home upon the Pazos Memorial.

22. VI:30. Easter Sunday— It has been a great question in the Newspapers whether Easter ought this year to be this day or the Next Sunday. This day was the real full moon; but the full moon of the Almanac is I believe a day sooner. Mr Forsyth, Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Relations called upon me. He came to ask for the Committee a communication of the papers that have passed relating to the proposed Mediation of England, between the United States and Spain; and also of what passed between Lord Castlereagh and me respecting Florida. Forsyth told me the Committee had it in contemplation to propose a Bill authorizing the President to take possession of East Florida, and asked me, if I should have any objection to it— I told him, personally none. If Congress chose to assume that attitude with Spain, and encounter its responsibility, so far as I should have to share it as a member of the Administration I was prepared for it— But I added, for the sense of the Administration you must ask the opinion of the President, and not mine— I believe the President’s opinion is not in favour of that measure. He said he had seen the President, and found him averse to it; but he should nevertheless be disposed to present it— The Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Relations has always been considered as a member in the Confidence of the Executive, and Mr Forsyth acted thus at the last Session— The President has hitherto considered him as perfectly confidential, and directed me to communicate freely to him the documents concerning foreign Affairs, particularly those with Spain, which I have done. Early in the course of the Session of Congress, I observed a paragraph circulating in the Newspapers, intimating that the Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Relations was destined to a Mission abroad, and Prussia was specially named as the Court to which he would be accredited. Mr Clay who has been marshaling his forces for a system of regular opposition to Mr Monroe’s Administration, in sneering hints and inuendo’s has been continually stinging Forsyth, as if he were a dependent tool of the Executive. Forsyth is a man of mild amiable disposition, and good talents, but neither by weight of character, force of genius or keenness of Spirit, at all able to cope with Clay. He has suffered himself to be goaded by Clay, not only into disavowals of any subserviency to the views of the Executive; and to declarations in the face of the house that he did not care a fig for the Administration or any member of it; but into the humour of proposing measures which the President utterly disapproves— From mere horror of being thought the tool of the Executive he has made himself the tool of Clay’s opposition. To manifest his Independence he has given broad hints of an intention to propose measures of actual hostility against Spain, and now is so far committed that he cannot withdraw from them. I told him that nothing had passed in writing on the subject of the mediation, but that if it was desired the substance of my Conversations with Lord Castlereagh concerning Florida, would be communicated to the Committee— Susan Buchanan returned from Mrs Frye’s, and we all spent the Evening at Mr Walsh’s— Mr Daggett, Senator from Connecticut, and Pitkin
and Hopkinson were there— They had some Conversation with me, concerning my late Correspondence with Onis, lately communicated to Congress. Hopkinson and Pitkin said they would call upon me to-morrow Evening to look over the maps, and see precisely the state of the questions respecting the boundaries. The French Minister, and Greuhm and ten Cate were also there— I had some conversation with Mr Hyde de Neuville, in which as he began to talk, about the hatred of the people of this Country to the house of Bourbon, I told him we knew that at the first restoration of Louis 18. there had been a deliberation of his Council, whether they should not declare War against the United States— Mr De Neuville appeared to be much offended at this, and in going away marked it so strongly, that Walsh was much struck with his manner, and spoke to me of it— I made light of it. De Neuville is a man of quick passions, and humours rather sudden than lasting. We came home about eleven.

23. VI: My journal has been for some days, and continues in arrears; while I am drafting observations on the Pazos papers— On calling this Morning at the President’s I found him in great agitation at having learnt Forsyth’s intention, to bring forward the motion for authorizing the President to take possession of East Florida— He had but just learnt the sallies that Forsyth has indulged himself in, before the House of Representatives to shew his Independence of the Executive— He had requested Mr Crawford to see Forsyth, and dissuade him from his proposed motion. Crawford came in while I was there— He had been with Forsyth; but without success— But Crawford said the other members of the Committee of Foreign Relations would not support Forsyth. The President desired him to see Mr Barbour, who is one of the Members of the Committee, and request him to call at the President’s this Evening. He said Forsyth’s project would be War; and if such a Bill should be presented to him by Congress, he would refuse to sign it. He should prefer of the two, to acknowledge the Independence of the Colonies. At the Office I had an uninterrupted succession of visitors all the Morning— Mr Bagot came, about the Salaries of the Commissioners under the Ghent Treaty Commissions— I had found upon examination that the principle upon which the Commissioners under the Treaty of 1794 had been compensated was that the Commissioners on both sides who crossed the Sea, should receive £1500 Sterling a year, and those who were at home £1000. As the present Commissions, are all in this Country, there is therefore no reason for a claim of the American Commissioners to receive as much as the British— Mr L. Harris came to take leave. He is going off to-morrow Morning, and left a supplementary account against the public with me. He said that the President had consented that he should write his nephew John to come home, without subjecting him to the mortification of being dismissed from Office— He said the President had told him his sentiments towards him were unchanged— He added that in the course of the late enquiry into his conduct, he had intimated to the President his apprehension that I had been unfriendly to him; but the President had assured him, I had observed the most perfect propriety concerning him— Mr Sergeant spent an hour with me this Evening. Miss Williamson came and lodged here to go in the morning in company with Susan Buchanan to Baltimore.

24. VI:Mr H. Nelson of the house of Representatives came to the Office to enquire if the Messages to Congress with the Documents relating to South-America, and those relating to Amelia-Island were ready to be sent in and was exceedingly urgent that they might be sent to-morrow, by twelve O’Clock—because Mr Clay was to make his motion, and Speech today— He Nelson had asked Clay to postpone it for one or two days for the documents to be sent in, but Clay had refused— Captain O’Connor came, to offer his Services as bearer of despatches to France. We had Company to dinner— Mr and Mrs Otis, Mr and Mrs Tucker, Mr and Mrs Middleton, Mr and Mrs Sears, and Miss Perkins, Messrs.Bloomfield, Dickerson, Johnson of Kentucky, Lacock, Mason, Roberts, Sanford, and S. Smith— Mr and Mrs Lowndes were invited, but declined coming. Mr and Mrs Sergeant also sent excuses—Mrs Sergeant being ill with a pleurisy— The party was quite a pleasant one, and the company left us about nine in the Evening— Mr Clay came out this day with part of his great opposition Speech. He moved in the general appropriation Bill, an appropriation of 18000 dollars for an outfit and a year’s Salary for a Minister to the Government of Rio de la Plata. This was merely a mode of proposing a formal acknowledgment of that Government. He spoke upon it this day about an hour, and is to finish his Speech to-morrow. Susan Buchanan left us this morning, and returned to Baltimore.

25. VII. This morning I received a Note from the President requesting me to call upon him and assist him, in collecting the papers to be sent in with his Messages. I went accordingly and after stopping a few minutes at his house, proceeded to the Office, and sent him the papers for two Messages to Congress, the one relating to South-America, and the other Supplementary Documents relating to the occupation of Amelia-Island— Two other Messages were also sent in this day— One concerning the Seminole War, and the other
upon the expences of the Ghent Treaty Commissions. Mr G. W. Campbell a Senator from Tennessee, came to the Office and had some Conversation with me, concerning the South-American Questions and the neutrality Bill— But we were interrupted, and he told me, he would call another day. When I came home, I found my wife very ill in bed— Evening retrieved in part arrears of the journal.

26. VII. My wife was very ill all night; and I was up between two and three in the Morning; took a cold foot bath and returned to bed— Rose again at seven. Mr N. Pope came and introduced Mr Speed, a member of the House of Representatives from Kentucky— Mr Southard also, a member of the House from New-Jersey likewise came to recommend a Printer of the Laws in that State. At the President’s I met Crawford— He and Crowninshield want to order one of the public armed vessels into Chesapeake Bay, to be on the watch against smuggling and these piratical privateers; but they are afraid of incurring the odium of opposing the Patriots, and so Crawford had the notable project of procuring from me, a demand that the admission of foreign armed vessels should be confined to certain Ports. This was merely and avowedly to procure my signature to be shewn in public as responsible for the measures adverse to the South-American Patriots— I met yesterday in the Avenue Hyde de Neuville, and ten Cate— Hyde affected not to stop and speak to me. Ten Cate, asked for an interview this day at two, to which I agreed; but he did not come. I am still overwhelmed with Calls from both Houses, and from Committees of both. My wife continued very ill, and confined to her bed, the whole day.

27. VI:30. I received yesterday a French Note from a person calling himself Joseph Antinori, requesting me to appoint a time when I could receive him; for which I appointed this Morning at ten O’Clock. He came and with a mysterious air and manner told me that his family name was really Antinori, but that he was the Duke de Brindisi a Neopolitan— That he had arrived about a month since at Philadelphia, whither he should immediately return and embark for Europe. He came upon a secret mission from one of the greatest Ministers of the State of the Age— From Prince Metternick the Austrian prime Minister. He came to tell me that a Treaty was concluded two years ago, at Rome, between Austria and England entirely by secret, signed by Lord Stewart for England, and by Mr Lebzeltern for Austria, against Russia— That in consequence of that Treaty and of the projects of Russia, which it was intended to counteract, the European Powers were preparing for War, which would soon break out— That Baron Tuyll would very shortly arrive here as Russian Minister. (We know that Tuyll’s destination is changed and that Poletica is coming in his stead) that he would come with many compliments, and fair words, and cajoleries, and would make propositions to us, to take side with her in the War— That he himself was instructed to come here, and by indirect means, to seek and obtain my acquaintance; to sound my opinions, and those of the Government and Public, here: but he had preferred coming to the point at once— He had therefore asked an interview of me, and he was charged to enquire, if the United States were favourably inclined to receive propositions from Austria, to take a part in this alliance against Russia, or whether they would determine to remain neutral. That as propositions would certainly be made to us by the Russian Minister; he on his part was instructed to say that if we would join in the Alliance of Austria and England, one object of which would be to break up the Russian Settlements on the North-west Coast of America, Austria would engage to secure to us, an Establishment in the Mediterranean, which we had been desirous of obtaining— I told him I should report to the President the substance of his communication; but he must be aware the President would enquire if he had produced any evidence of his being authorized to make it. He would not require a formal Letter of Credence, but something to shew his authority would be indispensable— He said that hereafter he had no doubt he should be regularly accredited, and would spin out into forty Notes, what he had now disclosed in a quarter of an hour; but that the manner of the Austrian Government was to begin by
suggestions of unaccredited agents, and if they found their propositions were acceptable to pursue the object further— I told him that it would not be necessary, for him to come to me again for an answer— That the Austrian Government might be sure any proposal coming from them would be received and considered with all the respect due to them; but no answer whatever could be given to anything proposed by a person totally unaccredited. He said he should return to-morrow towards Philadelphia, and in a few days embark for Europe— But as some notice might be taken of his having been in conference with me, there was another subject which he wished to give out, as his motive for obtaining it— He then presented me a paper, containing a petition for a grant of Lands to Italian emigrants; also for a privilege to set up, and carry on a Lotto Lottery, engaging to pay an annuity, and to furnish a frigate of forty guns, ready built and equipped, six years successively for the privilege. I told him that every application for a grant of Land, must be made to Congress, and that for a Lottery to the State Legislatures. He finally asked if he might report to the Austrian Government that, if they thought proper to accredit him to the United States, there would be no personal objection to him, on the part of this Government. I told him that not having the honour of any personal acquaintance with him, and presuming that he was equally unknown to the President, there could be no personal objection to him as an official agent of Austria, if she should think proper to accredit him— He then left me in doubt whether to consider him as an imposter, or a lunatic. I had afterwards some slight suspicions that he might be an emissary from Daschkoff, to entrap the Executive of the United States; at least so as to countenance a charge of having listened to proposals hostile to Russia— The man named King, a workman at the Navy-Yard came with his daughter, wife to a man named J. P. Moore, an American, Master of the Successo, one of Aury’s piratical privateers— He brought two Letters from Moore dated 17. and 18 of this Month at Charleston where he is in prison at the prosecution of the Spanish Consul— He also writes that Aury is in prison there— King said Governor Middleton had promised him to support a petition to the President to direct the prosecution against Moore to be dropp’d— Mr Watmough paid us a visit— At the President’s I met Mr Calhoun with General Bernard the Engineer, who had a map of the Mississippi from its mouth to above New-Orleans which he has been lately taking— At the Office, Mr ten Cate, the Chargé d’Affaires from the Netherlands came to converse with me, concerning the late Message and Report, upon the Negotiation with the Netherlands— He expressed himself to be in general well pleased with it, but said it seemed to manifest a determination not to renew the negotiation. I told him that was not at all intended— We should readily renew the Negotiation, if desired by his Government, and if they had any expedient to propose, by which the two obstacles to the conclusion of the Treaty, which had occasioned the suspension of the negotiation could be removed— That the difficulty on our part was occasioned solely by the difficulty on their’s— We were willing to give up ours, if they would abandon theirs. He asked if there was any question whether the Treaty of 1782 was yet in force. I said none— We considered it as yet in full force. He said his Government did the same— He made various other remarks, and said Mr Clay had a day or two since said in a Speech, that this Government had sent a Minister to the king of the Netherlands, before he had sent one here, which ten Cate said was a mistake— Mr Clay he said had forgotten poor Mr Changuion— Mr Calhoun called in at my Office, to see the last despatch from Mr Gallatin, upon South-American Affairs— I received voluminous despatches from Mr Erving at Madrid, and from Halsey and Worthington at Buenos Ayres— My wife is up again this day. I walked home with Mr Calhoun— After dinner I found myself too drowsy for writing.

28. V:30. At the President’s this Morning, I had the voluminous despatches from G. W. Erving, at Madrid, and from Worthington and Halsey at Buenos Ayres to read, but the President though convalescent is yet so weak, that he declined hearing them wholly read, and asked me to state the substance of them to him— When I told him that Worthington, one of the informal agents sent to South America, to collect information had been concluding a Treaty there; he said with quick and irritated tone—Dismiss him instantly—Recall him—Dismiss him! Now, to think what recommendations that man had! Dismiss him at once! and send him the notice of his dismission, by every possible channel— Send it to Halsey; though Halsey himself is recalled— However the Commissioners when they arrived there will have set all right— He then spoke to me of the Pennsylvania Militia fines; upon which he has adopted the opinion of the Attorney-General Mr Wirt, though opposite to that which he had formed before— He said he had misapprehended the facts. He desired me to examine particularly the question, and if I should come to a conclusion different from that of Mr Wirt, to delay the answer till further consideration. But the subject which seems to absorb all the faculties of his mind, is the violent systematic opposition that
Clay is raising against his Administration. Clay appears to have made up his Account to succeed Monroe in the Presidency, and supported his Election, in the expectation of being appointed Secretary of State. In this he was disappointed, and though offered the War Department declined accepting it, and from that moment formed the project of rising upon the ruin of the Administration— He therefore took opposition ground upon all the cardinal points of Policy, taken by the President, but most especially upon the Constitutional question concerning internal improvement and upon South American Affairs— On the Amelia-Island Affair, at the very outset of the Session of Congress he pronounced himself against it, and as one of his own Kentucky papers stated, broke ground within battering distance of the Message— From that day to this he has been indefatigable in every private company where he has been, in expressing disapprobation of that transaction, and of the mission to South America— The President told me that last Evening a Member of the Senate came to him and asked him, if at the Cabinet Meetings before the Commencement of the Session of Congress, the determination was taken not to acknowledge the Government of Buenos Ayres, professedly to the end that Congress might take the lead in the measure— And this was now enquired, obviously with a view to justify the present conduct of Mr Clay. The President answered that at that time the Questions were proposed, whether the Executive was competent to acknowledge the Independence of Buenos Ayres, and if so, whether it was expedient. That it had been concluded the Executive was competent. But that it was not expedient to take the step, without the certainty of being supported in it by the public opinion; which if decidedly favourable to the measure would be manifested by measures of Congress. Mr Monroe added, that if Mr Clay had taken the ground that the Executive had gone as far as he could go with propriety towards the acknowledgment of the South Americans; that he was well disposed to go further, if such were the feeling of the Nation and of Congress; and had made his Motion with that view, to ascertain the real Sentiments of Congress, it might have been in perfect harmony with the Executive. But between that and the angry, acrimonious course pursued by Mr Clay there was a wide difference— At the Office, I had a visit from General Bernard and his Aid, with Mr W. Lee—and afterwards from Mr Sanford of the Senate. The Northern Mail came in, after, I returned home from my Office— Mrs Adams spent the Evening at the French Minister, Mr Hyde de Neuville’s.

29. VI:30. I attended at the Hall of the House of Representatives, and heard Mr Holley of Boston; who has been lately chosen President of the Transylvania University in Kentucky. He gave us a discourse of nearly two hours, on the coincidence between natural and revealed religion, and the doctrine of general toleration. He was eloquent, and listened to with much attention— The house was crowded. From Church I walked nearly to the Georgetown Bridge, and back to my house, with Mr Hyde de Neuville— He came in and sat with me half an hour. The Conversation was upon the Affairs of South-America, and our quarrel with Spain. Mr De Neuville would be very desirous that the South-American Affairs should be settled otherwise than by the mediation of England, who he is afraid will mediate only for her own interests— He says that Pizarro is going or has already gone out of Office; and that Yrujo will be his successor— He talks of going himself next Summer to France; for which he says he has a permission— Mrs: Adams spent the Evening at Mr Middletons at Georgetown.

30. VI: I abandoned the Morning to reading, which although principally upon subjects connected with the business of my office, is as bad as idleness, for it throws indispensable writing in arrear— Mr O’Sullivan came again to urge his claim for an appointment as Consul at Tunis— I told him that Mr Anderson’s resignation not having been received no appointment to that Office would probably be made, during the present Session of Congress. He then asked for the appointment as Consul at Buenos Ayres. Mr Lowndes, the Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, came to make enquiries about certain appropriations. There is an objection against an appropriation for the Mission to South-America, upon the principle that the Commissioners ought to have been nominated
to the Senate— Mr Clay’s motion for an Appropriation for an outfit and year’s Salary for a Minister to the United Provinces of Rio de la Plata, was rejected in the House on Saturday by a vote of 115 to 45. At the President’s I mentioned to him O’Sullivan’s application to be appointed Consul at Buenos-Ayres. He immediately determined against it— At the Office, Mr D. Brent was absent, his brother Robert’s daughter Mrs Pearson, having died last Evening. General P. B. Porter was at the Office, upon the subject of a claim lately advanced by Mr Bagot for a vessel and cargo, British property, taken on lake Ontario, just before the commencement of the late War; carried in to Sackett’s harbour, and there condemned after the War began— General Porter intimated that his brother was interested in the property— Judge Thruston came also to the Office, to ask for a Son of his an appointment as one of the additional Clerks in the Department of State, for which I have requested an appropriation— The judge was a member of the Senate, from the State of Kentucky when I was of that Body; he looks very ill, and gave me a very distressing account of his State of health, which approaches very nearly to melancholy insanity— The President sent to the Office, to ask me to call upon him as I returned home, which I did. It was to consult with me upon Instructions to be given to Mr GallatinMr Rush and Mr Erving, in relation to Spanish and South-American Affairs— He had at first inclined, to accept the proposal if it should be made to us by the European Powers, of joining in the proposed Mediation between Spain and her Colonies— But now he thinks we ought to decline taking any part in it— As our interest is to promote the total Independence of the Colonies, while the Basis of the Mediation is a compromise between the claim of Spain to govern and the claim of the South-Americans to Independence. He desired me to make a draft of Instructions to Mr Gallatin, to be considered in a Cabinet Meeting— Mr Sergeant spent an hour with us this Evening. Mr Trimble cannot be satisfied without getting at the scrap of paper from Erving, speaking of a secret order of the Spanish Government to delay the decision in R. W. Meade’s case while there was a public order for despatching it— Sergeant who is on the Committee with Trimble, brought a note from Trimble to me asking for a declaration from me in general terms that there was evidence at the Department to that effect. I told Sargeant, that if Trimble would call at the Office he should see the paper— If the Committee wished to see it, they should; but if it was to be made public there must be a call for it from the House.

31. V:45. Drafted an answer to a Letter from James Barbour, Chairman of the Committee of the Senate on Foreign Relations, containing questions relating to the admission of American vessels into the Colonial dependencies of the several European Powers— I took it to the President’s and read it to him— He approved it; but asked me to shew it before I sent it in, to the Secretary of the Treasury. I therefore took it immediately over to Mr Crawford, who also approved it; but on examining at my Office the late Correspondence of Mr Gallatin, Eustis, & Mitchell the Consul at Martinique, I found the Answer must be drafted over again. I met at Crawford’s the Vice-President Tompkins, who yesterday took leave of the Senate for the remainder of the Session, and is about returning to New-York. At the President’s I met Calhoun, who had a map, and Letters from New-Orleans concerning the Seminole War. Mr Bagot came, to mention his intention of writing a Note for the free admission of British vessels from the Bahama Islands, into which he says vessels of the United States are admitted— He also spoke of various other subjects. Mr Silsbee, and Mr Hale, a member of the House of Representatives from New-Hampshire, came. Silsbee to enquire about his claim for the money paid to Decatur at Algiers, and the claim of Mr Jeremiah Lee of Boston, for having ransomed his brother from the Arabs; and Hale to ask after a man named Jewett; imprisoned somewhere among the South-American Patriots— Mr Brent my Chief Clerk was again absent, and the crowd of business and of papers gets into inextricable confusion by his absence— My wife spent the Evening at Dr Thornton’s. I was employed all the Evening, in preparing the new draft of Answer to Mr Barbours enquiries, which I could not finish.

Day. Continues as the preceding months of this year. As the Session of Congress draws to a close the pressure of business increases; as well as the Calls for Reports from both Houses; from many of their Committees and from individual members— The Correspondence with our Ministers abroad is entirely at a stand— May I not fall into idleness when the adjournment of Congress shall leave me leisure, but provide for the next Session, if I should be then yet here, with a better method of transacting the business. Congress have agreed to adjourn the 20th. of next Month— In the mean time I find it impossible to observe any regular mode of arrangement for business— The President’s illness has increased the Confusion. He has been confined now nearly a fortnight to his chamber.
